content:
Diagnosis:	Papillary thyroid carcinoma, T2N1M0, NTRK fusion positive

Management:	15 Jan 2024 Total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection
		02 Feb 2024 Commenced Larotrectinib 100mg BD

Histology:	Classical variant papillary thyroid carcinoma, 3.2cm primary tumor with extrathyroidal extension. 4/12 central compartment nodes positive. NTRK fusion detected on molecular analysis.

Current Situation:	Treatment review at 3 months of Larotrectinib

I reviewed [redacted name] today who is making excellent progress on targeted therapy. The neck swelling from residual lymphadenopathy has significantly decreased, with the largest node now measuring 1.2cm compared to 2.8cm pre-treatment on ultrasound performed last week. She reports good energy levels and has returned to work part-time as a teacher. Her voice has continued to improve following surgery, though she still notices mild hoarseness with prolonged speaking.

She has experienced some mild side effects from the Larotrectinib, primarily grade 1 fatigue and occasional dizziness which typically occurs in the evening after the second dose. Her liver function tests show mild transaminitis (ALT 82, AST 65) which has been stable over the past month and does not require dose modification at present. TSH is well-controlled on Levothyroxine 150mcg daily.

On examination today, there is no palpable cervical lymphadenopathy. The surgical scar is well-healed with no concerning features. Latest thyroglobulin has decreased from 42 to 8.4 indicating good biochemical response.

The plan is to continue Larotrectinib at current dose with monthly blood tests for LFTs and thyroglobulin. We will arrange a progress CT neck/chest in 8 weeks' time. I will review her again in clinic in 4 weeks with blood results. She understands to contact us if side effects worsen or new symptoms develop.

primary_cancer.histopathology_status: Classical variant papillary thyroid carcinoma, 3.2cm primary tumor with extrathyroidal extension

cancer_timeline.value: Total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection
4/12 central compartment nodes positive. NTRK fusion detected on molecular analysis
Ultrasound shows largest node decreased to 1.2cm from 2.8cm pre-treatment
Thyroglobulin decreased from 42 to 8.4 indicating good biochemical response

patient_facts.value: No palpable cervical lymphadenopathy, well-healed surgical scar
Mild transaminitis (ALT 82, AST 65) stable over past month

status_updates.value: Papillary thyroid cancer with nodal involvement showing good response to targeted therapy with Larotrectinib. Radiological and biochemical improvement with manageable toxicity
Significant decrease in lymphadenopathy and thyroglobulin levels indicating good response
Grade 1 fatigue and occasional dizziness, stable mild transaminitis
Continuing Larotrectinib 100mg BD, no dose modification required
Progress CT neck/chest in 8 weeks, monthly blood tests for LFTs and thyroglobulin
Review in clinic in 4 weeks with blood results
